Input to output.

Software/Hardware?

No. Gosh, and I was worried that I might make the riddle too easy. Another bonus verse, so let's hope there are enough clues here.

Original:

We stand as sentinels, the two of us

People from every class must pass

From me to my friend

From creation to destruction

Never out of order, no step ignored

There are many like us

In lands where strange tongues are spoken

But there are other places, like one island

Where I alone have a true counterpart

And my friend's counterpart is left

To pick up the pieces

Never explicitly called upon, oft overlooked

Who are we?

Bonus verse 1:

We operate within the machine

I arrange the bits just so

Preparing everything to go

My friend cleans up

And casts the dust to the wind

Freed to become something anew

Bonus verse 2:

If I became lazy and never build

The many functionaries will attempt to act

But a great fault will fracture every segment

A million tiny voices will call up the stack

This is by God seen

Plus a fix here, plus a fix there

I am whipped into shape

And the course of events is set right

Also, recall this guess that I thought was close:

Creation/destruction?
i have a feeling that this is addressing a specific part of a computer's hardware so how about RAM/ROM
Sounds more like a hard disk, with the disk stack and the write head.

But a great fault will fracture every segment

A million tiny voices will call up the stack

Sounds like a bug in software or something, and people complaining or something.

Something that runs in the computer like a game or something?

Software?
CD/Floppies? i am not sure i am just guessing
How about typing and deleting?
OS or BIOS?

code like java and a compiler

Okay, since we want this over, here is the answer with my reasoning:

We are the constructor and destructor

Para 1:

We stand as sentinels, the two of us

People from every class must pass

From me to my friend

From creation to destruction

Never out of order, no step ignored

Class was intended to indicate that people (objects) are part of a class

"creation to destruction" corresponds to 'constructor' and 'destructor'

Also, you can't destruct before you construct

Para 2:

There are many like us

In lands where strange tongues are spoken

But there are other places, like one island

Where I alone have a true counterpart

And my friend's counterpart is left

To pick up the pieces

Never explicitly called upon, oft overlooked

Who are we?

Many programming languages (tongues) have constructor and destructors

The island was supposed to be a play on Java (which is a language and an island). In Java, there isn't strictly a destructor, but rather a garbage collector. So the destructor ('my counterpart', since I'm the constructor), has to pick up garbage. Since GC is automatic, it rarely needs to be dealt with.

Para 3:

We operate within the machine

I arrange the bits just so

Preparing everything to go

My friend cleans up

And casts the dust to the wind

Freed to become something anew

Basically, this is in a computer: I construct, my companion destructs (which also frees up memory for new objects)

Para 4:

If I became lazy and never build

The many functionaries will attempt to act

But a great fault will fracture every segment

A million tiny voices will call up the stack

Para 5:

This is by God seen

Plus a fix here, plus a fix there

I am whipped into shape

And the course of events is set right

I'm the constructor ('build'). If an object isn't constructed, it is null, and calling a function on a null object/pointer will cause a segfault ('fault' 'segment') which goes up the call stack.

Here, God is the user, who fixes the code he wrote wrong that would let this happen.

'Seen Plus... Plus' was an attempted play at C++ to say that the constructor/destructor pair was intended to be partially interpreted as being from that language, as opposed to say Java from earlier.

Who has an easier riddle?

Okay, yep, that was way over my head.

I think I'll stand down for now, let someone else have a turn, unless there really is no one else to give a riddle.
